note.title: Singular and Ordinary Points
note.fname: Differential Equations.Series Solutions to Differential Equations.Singular and Ordinary Points

pageProps.body:
Singular and Ordinary Points

We define

Definition. (Singular and ordinary points.) If at a certain point x0x_0x0​ the Taylor series (power series) for q(x)p(x)\frac{q(x)}{p(x)}p(x)q(x)​ and r(x)p(x)\frac{r(x)}{p(x)}p(x)r(x)​ do not exist - most commonly because p(x0)p(x_0)p(x0​) is zero - that point will be a \it singular point\normalfont. Conversely, if the Taylor series of both functions at x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ do exist (the functions are analytic), then x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ is an ordinary point.

Definition. (Regular and irregular singularities.) Let x0x_0x0​ be a singular point of the aforementioned DE. Then if q(x)p(x)\frac{q(x)}{p(x)}p(x)q(x)​ contains no more than the first power of (x−x0)(x-x_0)(x−x0​) in its denominator when simplified, and r(x)p(x)\frac{r(x)}{p(x)}p(x)r(x)​ contains no more than the second power (x−x0)2(x-x_0)^2(x−x0​)2 in its denominator, x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ is a regular singularity. Otherwise, we deem it to be an irregular singularity.

Why is this so? For some singular points (namely, where q(x)p(x)\frac{q(x)}{p(x)}p(x)q(x)​ and r(x)p(x)\frac{r(x)}{p(x)}p(x)r(x)​ are undefined because p(x)=0p(x)=0p(x)=0 at x=x0x=x_0x=x0​), the answer is obvious: the coefficients themselves are undefined, meaning that the differential equation would not make sense. However, if - as the definition of a regular singularity goes - the maximum power of (x−x0)(x-x_0)(x−x0​) is 2 in r(x)p(x)\frac{r(x)}{p(x)}p(x)r(x)​, and 1 in q(x)p(x)\frac{q(x)}{p(x)}p(x)q(x)​, the power series solution for the DE

y=∑n=0∞cn(x−x0)ny=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n (x-x_0)^ny=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−x0​)n

can cancel out these powers of (x−x0)(x-x_0)(x−x0​) as long as the first few terms are zero. This leads us to the solution

y=∑n=0∞cn(x−x0)(n+σ),y=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n (x-x_0)^{(n+\sigma)},y=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−x0​)(n+σ),

also known as a Frobenius series, where σ\sigmaσ can be any complex number with c0≠0c_0 \neq 0c0​=0. This allows us to "skip" the first few terms of the Taylor series, and cancel out these pesky x−x0x-x_0x−x0​ terms in the denominator that result in dividing by zero. If instead the singularity is irregular, then the same method no longer applies; power series solutions may not exist, or may behave strangely, at that particular point.

Finally, at ordinary points where everything is well-defined, analytic, and has power series expansions, we simply have two linearly independent solutions of the form

y=∑n=0∞cn(x−x0)ny=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n(x-x_0)^ny=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−x0​)n

about the point x=x0x=x_0x=x0​.

Theorem. (Fuch's theorem). The second-order differential equation

y′′+p(x)y′+q(x)y=g(x)y''+p(x)y'+q(x)y=g(x)y′′+p(x)y′+q(x)y=g(x)

has a power series solution expressible in the form

y=∑n=0∞cn(x−x0)(n+σ)y=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n (x-x_0)^{(n+\sigma)}y=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−x0​)(n+σ)

near x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ if p(x)p(x)p(x), q(x)q(x)q(x) and g(x)g(x)g(x) are analytic at that point, or that point is a regular singular point. If instead x=x0x=x_0x=x0​ is an ordinary point, there exists two linearly independent solutions of the form

y=∑n=0∞cn(x−x0)n.y=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n(x-x_0)^n.y=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−x0​)n.
